title: 115_s1893
content: The Act may be cited as the "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017" and includes revisions to Council authority. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017" amends sections of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act related to the identification of global systemically important bank holding companies and enhanced supervision. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017" amends sections of the Dodd-Frank Act related to the identification of global systemically important bank holding companies and enhanced supervision. It includes changes to subsections regarding differentiation by the Council and reports on bank holding companies. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017" amends sections of the Dodd-Frank Act related to the identification of global systemically important bank holding companies and enhanced supervision. It includes changes to subsections regarding differentiation by the Council and reports on bank holding companies. The Act also amends sections related to mitigation and the Office of Financial Research, specifying criteria for global systemically important bank holding companies. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017" revises the authority of the board. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017" amends sections 163 and 164 of the Dodd-Frank Act to replace the asset threshold with criteria for identifying global systemically important bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision and prudential standards for global systemically important bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision and prudential standards for global systemically important bank holding companies by tailoring regulation based on specific criteria. The Dodd-Frank Act enhances supervision and prudential standards for bank holding companies not identified as globally systemically important, based on specific risk factors that could threaten US financial stability. Bank holding companies not identified as globally systemically important will be subject to enhanced supervision and prudential standards tailored to their risk level, based on specific factors that could threaten US financial stability. Council approval is required for regulations in this regard. The Board of Governors must have Council approval for regulations determining the supervision of bank holding companies based on factors like size and interconnectedness. The Board of Governors determines supervision of bank holding companies based on factors like global activity and complexity, ensuring consistent treatment for similar companies. Data already reported is used to avoid unnecessary burden. The Board of Governors will publish a list of identified global systemically important bank holding companies to avoid burdening them with unnecessary calculations. The Board of Governors will publish a list of global systemically important bank holding companies and seek feedback from the Council on the identification process. Amendments to the Federal Reserve Act include renumbering subsections and updating criteria for companies subject to assessments. The Act allows the Federal Reserve to set stricter standards for bank holding companies posing risks to the financial system. The amendments will take effect one year after enactment.
